thread.title: The great switch to owner-occupier loans
thread.title_full: The great switch to owner-occupier loans | afr.com

author: Duncan Hughes
title: The great switch to owner-occupier loans
text:
Banks are competing for business but beware of the small print. by Duncan Hughes Banks and other lenders are competing for home buyers looking to switch from interest-only to principle-and-interest loans with upfront discounts on establishment fees, lower interest rates and special offers for insurance and credit cards.
Some lenders claim thousands of borrowers are switching after regulators introduced higher rates for all interest-only loans and requirements for bigger deposits and more documented evidence of buyers' ability to pay for new loans.
"Home buyers and those living in their investment property are noticing the higher payments and realise it's time to switch," says Jessica Darnbrough, head of corporate affairs for Mortgage Choice, which represents a network of mortgage brokers.
Buyers can save about $75 a month on a $1 million mortgage repaid over 25 years by switching from the average interest-only to the average principal-and-interest product, according to Canstar, a company that provides comparative financial services information.
Bigger savings are available on fixed-term and packaged products, as explained below.
Refinancing may help Borrowers with interest-only loans who rent out their investment properties can negatively gear their interest payments to reduce their total outgoings.
"Refinancing can help owners to consolidate their debt, lower their home interest rates and potentially pay off their home loans sooner rather than later," Darnbrough says. "But it is not decision that should be made lightly. There are plenty of positives but also some negatives."
 Anecdotal evidence from lenders indicates a big surge in switches to principal-and-interest loans from interest-only products, which are popular with property investors because, as their name suggests, they require payment only of interest and not the principal, which is the amount borrowed.
Increased rates and tougher borrowing terms and conditions have been introduced because regulators are concerned buyer exuberance – or fear of missing out – is forcing some to borrow too much.
"It is clear the property investor landscape is changing," says Christopher Foster-Ramsay, managing director of mortgage broker Capital Home Loans. "Buyers are beginning to feel the impact. Lending conditions are likely to get tougher over the short term."
Variety of loans The average principal-and-interest loan rate is 4.5 per cent, based on a 25-year, $300,000 loan and a 80 per cent loan-to-value ratio, which is a measure of the buyer equity compared with the amount borrowed.
Reduce Home Loans is offering a standard variable "Rate Buster" at 3.94 per cent. Gateway Credit Union has a "package" special offer at 4.09 per cent and Newcastle Permanent is offering a three-year fixed loan at 3.89 per cent.
Terms and conditions can vary so it's important to check which offer best suits an individual borrower's circumstances.
A popular alternative for property buyers is to hedge their bets by splitting between variable and fixed-rate loans. While some are split 50-50, there can be variations depending on borrowers' appetite for risk.
For larger sums borrowed, some banks are likely to require more than half the loan to be variable.
Offset account In most cases, borrowers will forfeit their access to an offset account for the fixed amount. An offset account is a separate savings account where the balance is offset daily against the loan amount.
Other special deals are conditional on borrowers switching their transaction accounts and credit cards to the lender.
National Australia Bank and ANZ Banking Group are offering cash-back payments and other incentives to owner-occupier borrowers who switch from another lender.
For example, NAB is offering a variable rate of 4.15 per cent on its Homeplus mortgage products for new and refinancing loans between $250,000 and $750,000. It applies only to owner-occupier loans and principal-and-interest repayments. Borrowers are eligible for $1500 cash back if they have an existing transaction account and NAB credit card.
ANZ has countered with a $1200 cash-back deal. It also applies only to owner-occupier buyers and a lending minimum of $300,000.
Package sweeteners Other lenders are adding sweeteners in their loan packages ranging from discounts on contents and car insurance to income protection and lower-cost credit cards.
Those considering these options need to balance the potential savings with the red tape involved in switching existing accounts. There could also be exit and switching fees.
"Find out about any exit or deferred establishment fees that might apply upon paying out an existing loan early," Darnbrough says. "While exit fees were banned on all new loans taken out after July 1, 2011, they could still apply to loans taken out before this date.
"Many borrowers will look to refinance with a lender that boasts the cheapest interest rate. But just because a lender has the cheapest rate does not mean to say the product is the cheapest home loan overall, or the most suited to their needs."
Exit fees do not include break costs, which can be imposed if a borrower bails out of a fixed-rate loan before its term expires.
Possible expenses There could also be a range of upfront fees from the new lender, including loan application, valuation, settlement and government fees.
Lenders' mortgage insurance, which is required if borrowing more than 80 per cent of a property's value when refinancing, is not transferable from one home loan to another.
"Many home buyers do not realise this and it could be a considerable expense," Darnbrough says.
Those switching to a fixed-rate loan will also need to monitor the interest rate it will revert to and shop around for the best rate. Some standard variable rates are more than 40 basis points higher than comparable products, which over the life of a loan could add tens of thousands of dollars to the total cost.
